choices.text: Herpes-simplex virus

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

 

Infection with the Herpes simplex virus (HS) causes punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

 

Immunocompromised patients are more likely to develop HS esophagitis.

 

Endoscopic findings may include multiple discrete or coalescent small ulcers that appear superficial, punched out, or volcano-like.

 

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are seen here:

 

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Infected squamous epithelial cells show 3 M’s:
    • Molding of nuclear contours
    • Margination of chromatin to the periphery of nuclei
    • Multinucleation
  • Intranuclear inclusions:
    • Cowdry type A: acidophilic inclusion with surrounding clear halo
    • Equivocal cases require an HSV immunohistochemical (IHC) stain to confirm the diagnosis

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Causes larger, shallow ulcers and might involve deeper tissue layers, with "owl's eye" inclusions typically seen.

 

Option C. Candida: Presents typically as white plaques or linear fissures rather than punched-out ulcers.

 

Option D. Acid: Causes erosive esophagitis with continuous areas of inflammation rather than discrete ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: A dead body was found with Rigor Mortis all over the body, including hands and feet. The body was cold to touch, and post-mortem lividity was fixed and present all over the dependent areas. What is the estimated time since death? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-24 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

Post-mortem interval (PMI), 

 

1. Rigor Mortis (Post-Mortem Stiffening)

 

  • Begins: 2 hours after death (first appears in Myocardium, then upper eyelids)
  • Developing Stage: 2 hrs- 12 hours after death (extends from upper parts of body to lower parts, with last in hands and feet).
  • Developed Stage: 12-24 hours after death (Remains fully developed in whole body)
  • Passing stage: 24-36 hours (it passes way in the same order as it developed, that is top to bottom) 

 

2. Post-Mortem Lividity (Livor Mortis)

 

  • Begins: 1 hours after death.
  • Fully develops: 6 hours after death.
  • Gets fixed: Between 8-12 hours after death (it no longer shifts if the body is moved).

 

3. Algor Mortis (Cooling of the Body)

 

  • Starts: 1 hours after death.
  • Fully cold to touch: 20 hours after death.

 

In this case:

 

  • Rigor Mortis is present all over the body, including hands and feet → At least 12 hours have passed.
  • Post-Mortem Lividity is fixed → At least 8 hours have passed.
  • Body is cold to touch → Since temperature is not given, so this information does not help much in getting time since death

 

Based on these findings, the minimum time since death is 12 hours. So it can be more than 12 hours but not less. Hence most appropriate answer is 12-24 hours

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-2 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor mortis does not develop fully within 1-2 hours; it takes at least 6-12 hours to be fully established.

 

Option B. 4-6 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor mortis would only be developing, not fully spread to hands and feet.
  • Post-mortem lividity would not yet be fixed.

 

Option C. 6-12 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor Mortis would still be in the developing stage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Sequence of Rigor Mortis (Nysten’s Rule)

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device shown in the photograph: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lippes Loop

 

The contraceptive device shown in the photograph is the Lippes Loop, which is an inert, non-medicated intrauterine device (IUD). The Lippes Loop is categorized as a first-generation IUD and is one of the earliest forms of intrauterine contraception. Unlike modern IUDs, which often contain copper or hormones, the Lippes Loop does not contain any active substances.

 

It is made of plastic and has a distinctive S-shape, which was designed to fit within the uterus. However, due to its high failure rate compared to newer, medicated IUDs, it is not commonly used today. Modern IUDs are typically either copper-based (second-generation) or hormone-releasing (third-generation), which offer better efficacy and safety profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T 380 A: This is a second-generation IUD that contains copper. It is more effective than the Lippes Loop due to its medicated nature, which creates an inflammatory reaction toxic to sperm and eggs, preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Options B. Mirena and D. Levonorgestrel IUD (LNG-IUD): Mirena is a third-generation, hormone-releasing IUD that contains levonorgestrel, measuring 32 × 32 mm placed for up to 5 years

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lippes Loop is an older, non-medicated, inert IUD that was once widely used but has been largely replaced by more effective copper and hormone-releasing IUDs in modern contraceptive practice.

questions.text: What is the odor of a mummified body? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

A mummified body is characterized by the absence of moisture, leading to its preservation. This process results in the body becoming dry and leathery, which eliminates the conditions necessary for the growth of bacteria responsible for producing foul odors.

 

Mummification:

 

  • Odor: Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition.
  • Appearance: The body becomes dry and leathery, preserving it in a desiccated state.

 

Comparison with Other Types of Decomposition:

 

  • Adipocere Formation:
    • Odor: An adipocere body has a foul, rancid smell similar to decomposing fats.
    • Formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," forms when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation into a waxy substance, typically in moist environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pungent: This odor is might be present in cases of certain chemical exposures or other types of decomposition.

 

Option C. Putrid: This odor is characteristic of bodies undergoing typical decomposition, where bacterial activity produces foul-smelling gases.

 

Option D. Offensive: Similar to putrid, this term describes the unpleasant odors produced during the normal decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mummified body is odorless due to its dry and preserved state, an adipocere body which has foul rancid smell (like decomposing fats)

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6th left

 

The image depicts a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

 

Normally, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. However, in cases of PDA, the ductus arteriosus fails to close, leading to abnormal blood flow between the two major arteries.

 

Presentation - Hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

 

Treatment options for PDA include medication, minimally invasive catheter-based procedures, and surgical closure. Medications like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be given to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

The aortic arch arteries, also referred to as the branchial or pharyngeal arch arteries, are a series of six paired arterial structures that arise from the aortic sac during embryonic development. They play a crucial role in the formation of the major arteries of the head, neck, and thorax. Abnormal development or persistence of these arteries can lead to a range of congenital anomalies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 4th left and Option B. 4th right: These arches are primarily involved in forming parts of the aorta and its major branches, not directly related to the defect depicted in the image.

 

Option D. 6th right: While the right 6th arch also contributes to the development of the pulmonary artery system, its defects are usually not associated with PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:

 

  1. Double Aortic Arch: This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  2. Right Aortic Arch: This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  3. Interrupted Aortic Arch: Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  4. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus: This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  5. Coarctation of the Aorta: It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  6. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  7. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery: This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  8. Cervical Aortic Arch: Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  9. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects: These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  10. Vascular Rings: These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: In a case of RTA (Road Traffic Accident), a person has died. Who can order an autopsy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Police Officer


In cases of deaths such as those resulting from road traffic accidents, the decision to conduct an autopsy is made by the Investigating Officer (IO), typically a Police Officer. The Police Officer is responsible for the inquest, which involves examining the circumstances of the death and deciding whether an autopsy is necessary to determine the cause of death. While the actual conduction of the autopsy is performed by a forensic doctor, the authorization comes from the Police Officer handling the case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Public Prosecutor: The Public Prosecutor is involved in legal proceedings but does not have the authority to order an autopsy. Their role begins after the investigation and autopsy have been conducted and evidence is gathered.

 

Option B. Defendant Lawyer: The Defendant Lawyer represents the accused in legal proceedings and has no authority to order an autopsy. Their role is strictly legal defense, not investigative.

 

Option D. Forensic Medicine Doctor: The Forensic Medicine Doctor conducts the autopsy but does not have the authority to order one. They act upon the request of the Investigating Officer who is in charge of the case.

 

Educational Objective:


The Police Officer, specifically the Investigating Officer, has the authority to order an autopsy in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths, such as those resulting from a road traffic accident.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents is associated with an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane, like other inhaled anesthetic agents, causes vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels, leading to increased cerebral blood flow (CBF) and consequently increased intracranial pressure (ICP). All inhalational agents including sevoflurane increase cerebral blood flow and hence ICP. 
 

 Table of Anesthetic Agents and ICP Effects

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiopentone sodium: This is an intravenous anesthetic that actually decreases cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure. It's commonly used in neurosurgery and for patients with elevated ICP precisely because of this property.

 

Option C. Lidocaine - This is a local anesthetic that has minimal to no effect on ICP when used at clinical doses. When used systemically, it may actually have a mild ICP-lowering effect.

 

Option D. Propofol: This intravenous anesthetic decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolic rate, and consequently reduces intracranial pressure. Like thiopentone, propofol is often preferred in neuroanesthesia due to this beneficial effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All inhalational anesthetic agents, including sevoflurane, increase cerebral blood flow through vasodilation, which leads to increased intracranial pressure - an important consideration when selecting anesthetics for neurosurgical procedures.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Explanation:

 

The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.

 

While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.

 

Pernicious malaria -  (due to heavy parasitization)

 

  • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs

 

Other Options:

 

A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.
